9.text: I'm Jeff Hoffman. I'm professor of aerospace engineering

13.text: in the department of aeronautics and astronautics at MIT.

17.text: Prior to coming here, I spent 25 years at NASA as a NASA astronaut

22.text: and made five flights in various space shuttles.

26.text: I was the first astronaut to log 1,000 hours on the space shuttle,

31.text: and I was one of the crew in the rescue mission

34.text: for the Hubble Space Telescope back in 1993.

39.text: All over the world there are places where we can see the artificial borders

45.text: that humans have put up and the different ways that we take care

48.text: of the land on either side of the borders.

51.text: So, it's like the many other impacts

55.text: the Human race has had on our planet.

59.text: It's a situation where we've affected our planet

63.text: in ways that are visible from a cosmic perspective,

66.text: and it should give us pause.

69.text: I'm Karen Hudes. I'm known as the World Bank whistle-blower.

72.text: I'm working with a team of other whistle-blowers,

74.text: both from the World Bank and outside the World Bank,

77.text: to tell you what's been hidden from you—deliberately hidden from you.

82.text: The Federal Reserve system is a private system—it's not a central bank.

86.text: And these bankers are all part of a system

93.text: They own 40% of the assets of the 43,000 companies

99.text: that are traded on the capital market,

101.text: and they pull down 60% of the annual earnings.

105.text: They bought up all our media; and that media is hoodwinking the citizens.

110.text: At the vanguard of this new wave of automation is the field of robotics.

114.text: But instead of serving us, we find them competing for our jobs,

118.text: and, according to MIT professors Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee,

122.text: one of the reasons for the jobless recovery.

124.text: I’m Erik Brynjolfsson. I’m a professor at MIT

128.text: and the director of the MIT initiative on the digital economy.

132.text: Every new technology both destroys jobs and creates jobs.

137.text: There are winners and there are losers.

139.text: There’s disruption, and that’s certainly true with this wave,

142.text: even as it creates record wealth.

144.text: We’re now at $77 trillion with record productivity and record GDP.

149.text: There are a lot of people who are actually worse off than they were before.

153.text: My name is Abby Martin and I am a journalist for mediaroots.org

157.text: and a host of Breaking The Set on RT America.

162.text: The media’s morphed into just peddling the corporate interests

166.text: of the money masters that control the political establishment.

170.text: I don’t even consider us to live in a democracy at all;

174.text: there’s a corporatocracy that’s running the planet,

177.text:
and under this corporatocracy, we have them (corporations)
using the state as a tool of the market.

183.text: And so, we’re at a state now

185.text: [where] all of their interests [are] bleeding into the media.

190.text: My name is Paul Wright and I’m the executive director and the founder

195.text: I’m also the editor of 'Prison Legal News',

197.text: and I've published and edited three anthologies on mass incarceration,

202.text: starting with 'The Celling of America: An Inside look at the U.S. Prison Industry',

206.text: followed by 'Prison Nation: The Warehousing of America’s Poor',

210.text: and 'Prison Profiteers: Who Makes Money from Mass Incarceration'.

215.text: Generally, the laws in this country are written by the wealthy and the powerful

219.text: because, by definition, that’s who controls legislatures

222.text: and the commanding heights of the power system in this country.

227.text:
The government is not a neutral agent;
it serves the class that holds power.

233.text: I’m a professor of civil and environmental engineering at Stanford University,

238.text: and I build computer models to simulate climates, air pollution, and weather

244.text: on global, regional, and local scales.

246.text: I also study and develop solutions to the problems of

251.text: global warming, air pollution, and air-pollution health problems

255.text: with the goal of trying to provide energy stability for years to come.

260.text: There’s no technological or economic limitation to solving these problems;

264.text: it’s a social and political issue, primarily.

272.text: I am the recently retired host of 'The Dylan Ratigan Show' on MSNBC.

277.text: It was the highest rated non-primetime show on the network.

280.text: Prior to that, I was the host and creator

283.text: of a program on CNBC entitled 'Fast Money',

286.text: which was the single highest-grossing, highest-rated

289.text: show in the history of CNBC.

291.text: I have resigned all those positions 18 months ago

295.text: in order to follow the leadership

297.text: of recently-returned Iraq and Afghanistan war veterans

300.text: who have explained to me that the necessary solution to global conflict

305.text: is the tactical application of global resource management,

308.text: and I have devoted my life to helping them achieve that goal.

314.text: I’m a reporter for RT television

316.text: and host of 'Boom Bust', a financial and economic show on RT.
